results.title: Waterfront safety
results.creator_credit: Western Australia. Dept. of Labour and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This 1966 film takes place on the wharfs and ships at Fremantle Harbour, demonstrating safe working methods for waterside workers. It shows the correct handling of various types of cargo, including logs, grain and phosphate mined from Nauru. It emphasises the use of protective clothing and equipment. The film also shows the prevention and control of fires, including fire fighting ships.

Produced by the Western Australian Government Film Unit and presented by the Western Australian Department of Labour with Accident Prevention Organisation (Shipping).

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

group_works.title: Drift

results.title: Free shadow movies
results.brief_description: Like a filmic haiku, this very short film is a series of observations of the ‘free shadow movies’ that play on the streets of everyday life. Gathering images of light, time and motion from the most simple moments - a passing train, children playing - the filmmaker has created an immersion into urban mysteries of shadow and sensation. The result, while simple and modest, is a hypnotic perception of street life as glimpsed from the corners of the eye.

results.title: Drift
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and black and white, silent
results.brief_description: Since the first Apollo moon landing in the 1960s, NASA has compiled an enormous photographic record of its lunar saga. San Francisco photographer Michael Light gained access to the original negatives, presenting his collection of photography in major American and European museums including San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. As a reprise to his photographic exhibition ‘Full Moon’, Light has created ‘Drift’, an epic seven-minute loop of composite still imagery taken during NASA’s moon missions.

results.title: Waistlines and lifelines
results.creator_credit: Russell Gibbs, John Banks and Advent Films
results.brief_description: Ron has a weight problem. He tries massage and the crash diet, but to no avail. A heart attack scare sends him to his doctor, who recommends graded exercises and consultation with a dietician.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Russell Gibbs, John Banks and Advent Films

results.title: A Personal search
results.brief_description: In this autobiographical documentary, John Whitney, one of the best-known film and computer artists of our time, reflects on and explores his lifelong search for the complentarity of music and visual art, and the synthesis of film and computer technologies. In doing so, he describes current developments that foretell radical and exciting new ways viewers will soon be experiencing music and art.
results.description: In this autobiographical documentary, John Whitney, one of the best-known film and computer artists of our time, reflects on and explores his lifelong search for the complentarity of music and visual art, and the synthesis of film and computer technologies. In doing so, he describes current developments that foretell radical and exciting new ways viewers will soon be experiencing music and art.

group_siblings.title: Experiments in motion graphics
group_siblings.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio

results.title: Matrix
results.brief_description: Another of John Whitney’s important investigations into technology and the moving image, this particularly geometric animated abstraction uses industrial computers to render Whitney’s light musical forms onto the screen. Computer generated forms evolve, merge and subdivide on a black background, each motion and movement as carefully orchestrated and synthesised as the accompanying music.
results.description: Another of John Whitney’s important investigations into technology and the moving image, this particularly geometric animated abstraction uses industrial computers to render Whitney’s light musical forms onto the screen. results.title: Experiments in motion graphics
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: In this documentary film exploring his working processes, John Whitney explains some of the techniques and philosophies involved in programming and animating his computer-made abstract films. He attempts to define his new art of ‘motion graphics’ by comparison with music and language. As well as an intriguing investigation into his work, this film is a visual feast of his remarkable dynamic abstractions.
